admission date: discharge date: date of birth: sex: m service: medicine allergies: amiodarone cephalexin attending: chief complaint: ventricular tachycardia, acute mi major surgical or invasive procedure: percutaneous coronary intervention ventricular tachycardia mapping and ablation history of present illness: 74m with ischemic cm ef10-15%, pvd, prior vf arrest, sp icd placement on mexilitine and dofetilide at home. admitted to osh on with complaints of feeling weak, found to be in sustained vt 120bpm wo icd firing. en route the patient was cardioverted in the ambulance with 100j. he was then admitted to telemetry floor at hospital but had vf arrest on , with successful shock from icd. trop 5.4, cpks just over 100. mexilitine was discontinued and iv lido started at 2mgkgmin. on , he developed slurred speech and dizziness so lido was held and then decreased to 1mgminkg. since starting the lido he has been arrhythmia free, pacing at a rate of 60. at 10:30 p.m., he had an episode of vt 160-170s. he would have a run of this and then the nurse would see him pacing for about 10 beats at a rate in the 120s, then he would go back into vt 160-170s... eventually shocked x 2.- back to v paced. entire event was about 2 minutes. the patient was asymptomatic except for some palpitations. they then increased his lido to 2mgmin after giving him a 50mg bolus. past medical history: 1) ischemic cm with an ef of % 2) sp vf arrest during his cea sp icd placement , 3) prior cvas, cea 4) pvd sp fem , right bka 5) copd 6) hx of complete heart block 7) hx of amio pulmonary and liver toxicity in . 8) unequal pupils trauma as child social history: he lives alone in . he is a retired manual laborer. he has no known drug allergies. he has two brothers, alive and well. physical exam: vs: 14655 hr 60 rr 18 sat 99%3l nc gen: wnwd man in bed in nad. heent: pupils unequal (chronic, per patient) mmm, no icterus. cv: ivvi hsm across precordium pul: cta bl, no wheezes or rales. abd: soft, nt, nd bs ext: r above-the knee amputation, lle wo edema. neuro: alert oriented x1 while on lidocaine gtt. pertinent results: 08:18pm blood wbc-10.1 rbc-4.84 hgb-14.5 hct-42.8 mcv-88 mch-30.1 mchc-34.0 rdw-15.5 plt ct-215 03:00pm blood pt-15.7 inr(pt)-1.6 08:18pm blood glucose-120 urean-21 creat-0.8 na-135 k-4.1 cl-100 hco3-26 angap-13 06:03am blood alt-17 ast-62 alkphos-70 totbili-1.3 08:18pm blood albumin-3.3 calcium-8.2 phos-2.6 mg-1.8 ekg: dual chamber pacemaker in atrio-ventricular sequential pacing mode. compared to the previous tracing of no diagnostic change. brief hospital course: 74m wischemic cm, pvd, prior vf arrest sp icd on mexilitine and dofetilide at home admitted to osh wvt 120 bpm and cp. at osh, found to have likely nstemi (trop 5.4) transferred to for cath ep study. cath w80% rca sp 2 stents. now persistent vt and icd firing, intubated on electively to sedate pt. 1. cardiovascular: a. rhythm: mr. has an icd that was initially placed in after an episode of vf arrest during his carotid endarterectomy. he was maintained on dofetilide, mexilitine and metoprolol at home. he presented to an osh complaining of weakness and was found to have an acute mi and episodes of vt. mexilitine was held and lidocaine drip was started but discontinued after pci on due to confusion and disorientation. on , he received his dofetilide dose somewhat late and developed persistent pulseful vt. lidocaine was re-started. the icd settings were modified and his heart rate was lowered back to 60bpm. the icd would attempt to pace him out of the vt with anti-tachycardia pacing but 13 episodes would cause him to be shocked. he recieved approximately 30 shocks. for patient comfort, he was intubated and sedated electively. with the lower heart rate in addition to switching lidocain to procainamide, the vt resolved. on - went to ep and had ablation which was sucessful. on , off of the dofetilide and procainamide, the patient was still having nsvt. ep recommended starting quinidine 324mg po tid. this was done, but then the pt developed severe diarrhea and fever that was thought to be quinidine. he was then started on procainamide, which he will be discharged on. the procainamide decreased the amount of nsvt to 1 or 2 runs of beats per 24 hours. he continues to have palpitations. b. ischemia: on admission here, he ruled in for mi and went straight to cath. he was found to have lesions in his rca. two drug-eluting stents were placed without complications. he will continue aspirin, plavix, and metoprolol. and post-op from the ep procedure, his acei moexipril was changed to captopril. c. pump: ef 10-15% per echo in , but the patient had no signs or symptoms of decompensated heart failure. he was kept on strict ios. digoxin was discontinued as it is arrythmogenic and he has been well-compensated. he was also kept on moexipril 15 , aldactone 25mg qd for hypokalemia, lasix 80 po qd for now. 2. pulm: intubated electively during persistent vt icd firings to allow sedation. successfully extubated . 3. mental status: confused but redirectable in holding area; apparently some correlation with lido administration, which were relatively high doses. not hypotensive. a head ct was done for unequal pupils post-op but on clarification, he has had unequal pupils since childhood. this mental status change improved when lidocaine was stopped. 4. thrombocytopenia: his platelet count dropped slowly, heparin dependent antibodies were sent and are neg. 5. diarrhea: pt developed severe diarrhea x 72 hours after one dose of quinidine. stool studies were neg for infectous etiology including c.diff. this diarrhea was attributed to quinidine and improved with holding of the medication. 6. increasing cr: the patient was noted on routine labs to have an increasing creatinine on the day of discharge. his aldactone was held, and he was discharged to follow up with dr. (general cardiology) in 1 week for re-check and follow up on restarting aldactone. medications on admission: imdur plavix univasc asa tykosin niaspan lopressor spivira inhaler dig protonix lido gtt. discharge medications: 1. aspirin 325 mg tablet, delayed release (e.c.) sig: one (1) tablet, delayed release (e.c.) po daily (daily). disp:30 tablet, delayed release (e.c.)(s) refills:2 2. clopidogrel bisulfate 75 mg tablet sig: one (1) tablet po daily (daily). disp:30 tablet(s) refills:2 3. atorvastatin calcium 80 mg tablet sig: one (1) tablet po hs (at bedtime). disp:30 tablet(s) refills:2 4. moexipril hcl 15 mg tablet sig: one (1) tablet po bid (2 times a day). disp:60 tablet(s) refills:2 5. metoprolol succinate 100 mg tablet sustained release 24hr sig: 1.5 tablet sustained release 24hrs po daily (daily). disp:30 tablet sustained release 24hr(s) refills:2 6. ciprofloxacin 250 mg tablet sig: two (2) tablet po q12h (every 12 hours) for 10 days. disp:40 tablet(s) refills:0 7. procanbid 1,000 mg12hr tablet sustained release 12hr sig: one (1) tablet sustained release 12hr po twice a day. disp:60 tablet sustained release 12hr(s) refills:2 8. pantoprazole sodium 40 mg tablet, delayed release (e.c.) sig: one (1) tablet, delayed release (e.c.) po q24h (every 24 hours). disp:30 tablet, delayed release (e.c.)(s) refills:2 9. tiotropium bromide 18 mcg capsule, winhalation device sig: one (1) cap inhalation daily (daily). disp:30 cap(s) refills:2 discharge disposition: extended care facility: baypointe - discharge diagnosis: ventricular tachycardia non-st elevation mi diarrhea discharge condition: good discharge instructions: if you have these symptoms, call your doctor: - shortness of breath - icd firing (shocks) - chest pain - dizziness - visual changes followup instructions: please see dr. within 1 week of discharge. , m. please follow up with dr. in weeks (call to verify your appointment)

admission date: discharge date: date of birth: sex: f service: this discharge summary covers the from through . chief complaint: hypoxia. history of present illness: this is a 62 year old female with pancreatic carcinoma originally admitted to the hospital on , with complaints of nausea, vomiting and dizziness. she was found to have left hydronephrosis. on the floor, she became more hypoxemic to 93% on non-rebreather and was transferred to the intensive care unit on and was intubated there. she had been started on ampicillin, gentamicin and flagyl for klebsiella urosepsis versus cholangitis on . during her intensive care unit course, the patient had four out of four blood cultures positive for klebsiella and had a percutaneous nephrostomy to relieve left hydronephrosis and an emergency room ct scan which was negative for cholangitis. the patient was treated for klebsiella bacteremia in the intensive care unit and had a left lower lobe pneumonia, and was started on ceftriaxone and flagyl. she was extubated on . she received aggressive chest physical therapy and nebulizers to allow for this but had a persistent o2 requirement upon transfer back to the floor on . her oxygen requirement there increased daily as well as her white blood cell count. on , her antibiotics were changed to a broader spectrum, zosynvancomycin, and she continued to become more hypoxemic. her oncologist, dr. saw her on the floor and was reluctant to start palliative chemotherapy until her infection issues were resolved. she was febrile on the floor up to 101.7 f., on . on the day of transfer to the intensive care unit she looked worse clinically with a saturation down to 91% on 50 liter face mask, on 90 to 93% on nonrebreather, and the medical intensive care unit team was asked to evaluate. medications on transfer: 1. heparin 5000 units subcutaneously three times a day. 2. protonix 40 mg p.o. q. day. 3. regular insulin sliding scale. 4. vancomycin one gram intravenous q. 12, day three. 5. zosyn 4.5 mg intravenously q. six, day three. 6. msir 50 mg q. four to six hours p.r.n. 7. ativan 0.5 mg p.r.n. 8. zofran 4 mg intravenously q. six hours p.r.n. 9. benadryl p.r.n. 10. tylenol. 11. atrovent. 12. albuterol p.r.n. past medical history: 1. hypercholesterolemia. 2. klebsiella pneumonia. 3. urinary tract infection. 4. osteopenia. 5. pancreatic cancer with liver metastases. 6. thyroid disease. social history: one half pack per day smoker times many years. allergies: no known drug allergies. family history: no history of cancer. review of systems: the patient denies dyspnea, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other pain. she wishes to have all possible medical interventions. physical examination: vital signs upon transfer are temperature 100.8 f.; pulse 107; blood pressure 9750; saturation of 93% on 100% nonrebreather; respiratory rate 25; arterial blood gas was 7.48, 30, 8, 58. fingerstick was 109. in general, an thin elderly female on a nonrebreather, tachypneic, alert and oriented times three. head: extraocular movements are intact. dry mucosal membranes. neck with right internal jugular catheter in place. cardiovascular: tachycardic, s1, s2, no murmurs, rubs or gallops. abdomen soft, nontender, nondistended, positive bowel sounds. back with no costovertebral angle tenderness; left nephrostomy in place. pulmonary: bronchial breath sounds in left base with egophony and dullness to percussion in the left base; otherwise clear to auscultation. extremities with no cyanosis, clubbing or edema, warm, well perfused. dorsalis pedis pulses bilaterally. neurological intact. laboratory: white blood cell count 33.4, hematocrit 25.8, platelets 386, inr 1.4. chem 7 was sodium 138, potassium 3.9, chloride 97, bicarbonate 28, bun 8, creatinine 0.5, glucose 94. alt 15, ast 28, ld 557, alkaline phosphatase 203, total bilirubin 2.0, amylase 75, lipase 44. calcium 7.5, phosphorus 2.6, magnesium 1.6, albumin 2.3. repeat chest x-ray showed a left lower lobe consolidation, patchy bilateral infiltrates versus pulmonary edema. micro-data was unrevealing since four of four blood cultures positive on for klebsiella. ct scan of the abdomen on revealed left lower lobe atelectasis, small bilateral pleural effusions and numerable liver metastases and spleen metastases and interval resolution of left hydronephrosis. initial impression was a 62 year old female with pancreatic cancer metastatic to liver, left hydronephrosis, status post left nephrostomy, status post recent klebsiella pneumonia bacteremia with worsening hypoxia and infiltrate on chest x-ray; slightly elevated total bilirubin and leukocytosis. medical intensive care unit course by problem: 1. acute respiratory failure: the patient was initially hypoxemic believed to be secondary to congestive heart failure in the setting of aggressive volume resuscitation with sepsis. initially, the patient was brought to the intensive care unit and started on the must protocol. stim test was negative. the patients initial lactates were in the 2 range and she was given one unit of packed red blood cells for her low hematocrit. the patient initially had ambisome started, however, this was discontinued after she was afebrile for 24 hours. she had a persistent o2 requirement in the intensive care unit and was on a nonrebreather mask for two days, however, with diuresis and antibiotics she was able to avoid intubation and in fact be weaned on her high flow face mask very slowly. the patient was initiated on aggressive chest physical therapy as well as suctioning. she was able to provide sputum which did not grow out anything and after diuresis she did well. an echocardiogram was performed which showed a normal left ventricular ejection fraction with impair left atrial relaxation and so it was assumed that the diastolic congestive heart failure could be related to her respiratory failure. the patient also had gentamicin initially started upon transfer to the unit, however, this was discontinued along with ambisome on and the must protocol was discontinued on as she was afebrile, her blood pressure stable and her lactate was only 1.2. 2. hypotension: the patient was initially hypotensive upon transfer to the unit. this improved upon diuresis. the patient was noted to become hypotensive acutely after morphine administration. a fentanyl patch was started for pain control with p.r.n. msir p.o. around the clock which seemed to hold her blood pressure up better. the patient was not on any pressors in the unit. 3. pancreatic cancer: the patient achieved pain control with morphine p.r.n. as well as a fentanyl patch. palliative chemotherapy was not an option given her infectious issues and the patients family initially wanted her to be a full code with aggressive care. however, upon multiple discussions with the family and the patient, the family is now resolved to having the patient be a do not resuscitate do not intubate and transfer to hospice; however, the patient herself wished to remain a full code and these issues remained unresolved at the time of transfer out of the unit today. her bilirubin was rising in the unit to a high of 2.4, however, it had started to fall after this and no other interventions were done. her inr was elevated to a high of 1.6, however, dropped back down to 1.3 after 5 mg of vitamin k subcutaneously. other liver function tests were stable in the unit. 4. nutrition: the patient was initially kept npo, however, she was able to tolerate clear liquids. by the time of discharge, the patient was started on tpn and was kept on tpn throughout the unit stay. 5. left picc line and a-line: right ij triple lumen catheter was pulled once a left picc line was placed and tip sent for culture which never grew out anything. the patient had a-line discontinued upon transfer back to the floor. 6. endocrine: regular insulin sliding scale, fingerstick four times a day. 7. infectious disease: urine culture positive for yeast on ; the foley catheter was replaced and a recheck of urinalysis was negative. repeat urine cultures did not grow out anything and so she was not started on any anti-fungals for this. however, she did have a positive yeast infection by clinical examination and was on three days of miconazole intravaginal suppositories. 8. depression anxiety: the patient was actively going through the acceptance stages for dying as she had been told that she has a very grave prognosis; angry at house staff at times, refusing to participate in getting out of bed or chest physical therapy at times, however, does it with encouragement. the patient was started on ritalin empirically to treat depression and fatigue and malaise while in the intensive care unit. the rest of her hospital stay should be dictated by the floor team accepting her. dr. , 12-207 dictated by: medquist36 d: 14:30 t: 15:29 job: admission date: discharge date: date of birth: sex: f service: acove medicine service addendum: the patient is a 62-year-old female. this will serve as an addendum to the discharge summary that was previously dictated. the hospital course did not change significantly for her metastatic pancreatic cancer. the patients case was discussed with her primary oncologist (dr. ) who felt that given the patients poor functional status and extremely grim prognosis that the patient was likely not a candidate for palliative chemotherapy. for hypoxic respiratory failure, the patient continued on a 50% face mask. her oxygen saturations ranged from 94% to 98%. the patient was also maintained on vancomycin, zosyn, and flagyl until she completed a 14-day course; which she completed prior to discharge. otherwise, the patient had no further episodes of desaturations and no further admissions to the medical intensive care unit for hypoxic acute respiratory compromise. for diastolic congestive heart failure, the patients goals were to maintain even input and output. she was started on a beta blocker at 12.5 mg twice per day for tachycardia. the patients tachycardia was felt likely secondary to pain; although, in the setting of a deep venous thrombosis a pulmonary embolism could not be ruled out. for deep venous thrombosis, the patient had lower extremity doppler studies given that she had asymmetric lower extremity edema which were significant for bilateral deep venous thrombosis extending from the femorals to the popliteals bilaterally. the patient was started on heparin and coumadin. her inr was not therapeutic at the time of discharge and was 1.4. the patient was to be continued on heparin drip at 1100 units per hour as well as coumadin until her inr is greater than 2. this was to be continued at . for pain, the patient was maintained on a fentanyl patch which was increased to 125 mcg q.72h. her ms04 intravenous was discontinued, and the patient was continued on morphine sulfate immediate release at 30 mg one by mouth q.6h. with good pain control. for fluidselectrolytesnutrition, the patient was continued on total parenteral nutrition and full liquids. her diet should be advanced at as tolerated. the patients total parenteral nutrition orders will be sent with the patients discharge paperwork. for prophylaxis, the patient was maintained on heparin, and coumadin, proton pump inhibitor, and a bowel regimen. she was also ambulated from bed to chair. for decubitus ulceration, the patient developed a decubitus ulceration to which duoderm was applied and remained stable during her hospitalization. the patients code status was full. for hematologic issues, the patients hematocrit levels remained stable throughout her hospitalization. it should be noted that the patient has a transfusion reaction to blood and should be given benadryl prior all blood transfusions. discharge diagnoses: 1. metastatic pancreatic cancer. 2. bilateral lower extremity deep venous thrombosis. 3. respiratory failure. 4. status post nephrostomy. 5. diastolic congestive heart failure. discharge instructionsfollowup: 1. the patient should have a follow-up appointment with her primary care physician within two weeks of discharge. 2. the patient should have her electrolytes and complete blood count checked regularly as she needed transfusions and will be on total parenteral nutrition. 3. the patients inr level should also be checked to insure that she is therapeutically anticoagulated. 4. the patients diet should be advanced as tolerated so that she can get off total parenteral nutrition if at all possible. condition at discharge: the patients condition on discharge was fair. she was stable on 50% face mask without desaturations. she was tolerating total parenteral nutrition and full liquids. she was able to ambulate from bed to chair. her blood counts have remained stable. discharge disposition: the patient was to be discharged to for physical as well as pulmonary rehabilitation. medications on discharge: (the patients medications on discharge included) 1. ipratropium nebulizers 1 q.6h. as needed. 2. albuterol nebulizers 1 q.4h. as needed. 3. albuterol nebulizers 1 q.4h. as needed. 4. methylphenidate 5 mg one by mouth in the morning. 5. morphine sulfate 30 mg one by mouth q.6h. as needed (for pain). 6. pantoprazole 40 mg one by mouth once per day. 7. metoprolol 12.5 mg one by mouth twice per day (to be advanced as tolerated). 8. senna 8.5-mg tablets one tablet by mouth twice per day as needed. 9. bisacodyl 5-mg tablets two tablets by mouth once per day as needed. 10. docusate 100 mg one by mouth twice per day as needed. 11. coumadin 5 mg one by mouth at hour of sleep (to be adjusted based on inr). 12. lorazepam 0.5-mg tablets one tablet by mouth q.4-6h. as needed (for anxiety). 13. fentanyl patch 125-mcg transdermal patch q.72h. (to be titrated up as needed). . 14. zofran 4-mg tablets one tablet by mouth q.4-6h. as needed (for nausea). 15. heparin drip at 1100 units per hour until inr greater than 2. 16. benadryl 25-mg tablets one tablet by mouth prior to transfusion of blood products. it should be noted that the patients code is a full code. , m.d. dictated by: medquist36 d: 12:02 t: 12:37 job: admission date: admission date: discharge date: service: cardiothoracic surgery history of present illness: this patient is an 82-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease and a history of cll diagnosed in . he had been on medications off and on for several weeks prior to admission. in addition, the patient had a platelet count of 121 in when admitted from the emergency department for angina and was transfused for further management of unstable angina. he was given the diagnosis of drug-related itp. the patient also has a history of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and coronary artery disease, with a catheterization in with 100% main right coronary artery, high-grade lad stented. he was readmitted in with chest pain. the patient presented to the emergency department prior to admission with exertional angina and chest pain. ekg showed lateral changes. the patient had a positive troponin, flat ck, positive mbi, and was admitted for decreased platelets and nst emi. past medical history: 1. diabetes. 2. hypercholesterolemia. 3. hypertension. 4. cll. 5. leg swelling. 6. drug-related itp. medications: 1. metoprolol. 2. nexium. 3. norvasc. 4. vitamin e. 5. glucotrol. 6. isosorbide. 7. lipitor. 8. furosemide. 9. ecotrin. 10. centrum silver. physical examination: he was an elderly man in no apparent distress, alert and oriented, afebrile with a blood pressure of 11744, heart rate 20, saturating at 98% on four liters nasal cannula. heent: examination significant for two small lesions in the left buccal mucosa. neck: no lymphadenopathy. cardiovascular: regular rate and rhythm. lungs: clear with a few crackles at the bilateral bases. abdomen: soft, nontender, nondistended, positive bowel sounds. extremities: few scattered petechiae, no ecchymoses or erythema, warm and nontender. examination was significant for a 1-2 cm axillary node on the right which was mobile and nontender. laboratory data: admission laboratory studies showed white count of 7.4, hematocrit 28.8, platelet count 26 from 31, 7% bands, 45% lymphocytes, 41% polys, and 7% monocytes. cpk was 102 to 122, troponin i 0.32 to 0.44. chest x-ray showed interstitial edema and curly b lines. urinalysis showed large blood, trace protein, 0-2 white blood cells. chemistries were within normal limits. potassium was 4.1 and creatinine 0.9. smear showed decreased platelet spherocytes. hospital course: the patient was started on prednisone for a presumed diagnosis of drug-induced itp, 60 mg p.o. q.d. all home cardiac and diabetic medications were continued. the patient was continued on prednisone, being followed by hematology-oncology, and angina was being treated by medical management and monitoring. the patient was stable on the floor with severe thrombocytopenia being followed by hematology until , when he developed the acute onset of anginal symptoms and flash pulmonary edema with hypotension. the patient was transferred to the unit. diabetes was being managed by glipizide, cardiac diabetic diet, and q.i.d. fingersticks. hematologically the patient was continued on prednisone and had platelets and packed red blood cells on call for transfusion for possible catheterization. hematocrit was to be greater than 30. the patient was clinically improving throughout the course in the intensive care unit with platelets up to 39, stable white count, stable laboratory studies otherwise. cardiac and antidiabetic medications were continued and the patient was doing well. the patient continued his course in the coronary care unit, was afebrile with stable vital signs on metoprolol, isordil, captopril, amlodipine, lipitor, levofloxacin, prednisone, glipizide and insulin sliding scale. white blood cell count was 13.3 from 14.8, hematocrit of 32.5 and platelet count 49 up from 37. electrolytes were stable. from a cardiac standpoint the patient was clinically improving with no further chest pain, normal sinus rhythm, and an out of sinus bradycardia. from a respiratory standpoint the patient was having a productive cough with improved oxygen saturations and responding to diuretics with decreased crackles on examination. the patient was on levaquin day three for possible right lower lobe pneumonia, and fingersticks, regular insulin sliding scale, and glipizide were being administered for diabetes. hematologically, the patient had an increase in platelets. prednisone dose was increased to 120. the patient had a stable hematocrit and heparin was being held due to decreased platelets. on the patient was afebrile with stable vital signs. laboratory studies were significant for a platelet count of 83 from 77 and glucose of 271. coagulation studies included a pt of 12.5, ptt of 30.4, inr 1. cultures showed coagulase-positive staphylococcus aureus sensitive to levaquin. the patient was status post coronary artery bypass grafting x 1 off pump, left internal mammary artery to left anterior descending coronary artery. please refer to operative note. the pericardium was left open. lines included an a line and a swan-ganz catheter. wires included two ventricular and zero atrial wires. tubes included a right and left chest tube and one mediastinal tube. on transfer to the recovery unit the patient was in normal sinus rhythm with a mean arterial pressure of 69, central venous pressure of 8, pad of 13, of 20. drips included levophed, nitroglycerin and health until the morning prior to admission when he awoke with acute onset of nausea, vomiting and diarrhea as well as some incontinence of stool. the morning of admission the patient woke up with shortness of breath and was diaphoretic and had chest pain. he presented to hospital and was found to have a ck of 1773 and troponin i of 62.95 and a potassium of 6.1. he was treated with four baby aspirin and was started on nitroglycerin drip, was given 80 mg of intravenous lasix, 10 units of intravenous insulin, one amp of d50, calcium gluconate, aggrastat and then became chest pain free. he was transferred to for emergent cardiac catheterization. this showed a 60 to 70 percent left main stenosis, left anterior descending coronary artery with a widely patent stent, and in the midvessel, there was 40 percent stenosis. the left circumflex had a 50 to 60 percent stenosis at the origin and a previously placed right coronary artery stent was widely patent. there was a totally occluded posterolateral branch and moderate pulmonary hypertension. hemodynamics revealed a pulmonary artery pressure of 4928, cardiac output of 2.1 with an index of 1.3, svr 2667 and pulmonary artery saturation of 39 percent. no culprit lesion was identified. past medical history: coronary artery disease, status post several sntemis, in , inferolateral myocardial infarction, status post percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty of his right coronary artery. in , he had right coronary artery stent for 90 percent proximal stenosis. he was also noted at that time to have three vessel disease and left ventricular end-diastolic pressure of 18. his ejection fraction at that time was 36 percent. on , he had a cardiac catheterization which showed left diffuse three vessel disease, left main had 60 percent maximal stenosis, his proximal midvessel left anterior descending coronary artery had a 50 percent stenosis. he also had proximal 60 percent stenosis in the left circumflex. he also had 80 percent stenosis in the obtuse marginal two and diffusely diseased obtuse marginal three. the right coronary artery stent that was placed in , was widely patent. he subsequently had stents of the left circumflex and obtuse marginal two. a repeat catheterization was done two weeks later on , and at that time he underwent stenting to his left anterior descending coronary artery. type 2 diabetes mellitus. congestive heart failure with an ejection fraction of 15 percent. end stage renal disease on hemodialysis monday, wednesday and friday. gastroesophageal reflux disease. history of gastrointestinal bleed. anemia. history of falls. history of cerebrovascular accident in . legally blind. diabetic neuropathy. hypertension. dyslipidemia. history of nonsustained ventricular tachycardia. allergies: shellfish which causes hives. medications on admission: 1. lasix 80 mg p.o. twice a day. 2. aspirin 325 mg once daily. 3. plavix 75 mg once daily. 4. there was no culprit lesion identified on his cardiac catheterization and the patient was treated medically for a non st segment elevation myocardial infarction. the patient was continued on aggrastat, aspirin, plavix and heparin. the patient was continued on beta blocker, ace inhibitor. the patient also had a swan-ganz catheter placed for optimal hemodynamic monitoring and was started on natrecor with hopes of improving cardiac output and indices through afterload reduction. because of the patients bacteremia (see below), the patient was not felt to be an optimal surgical candidate at this time. additionally, as the patient had been having rigors (see below), and was noted to have elevated cks with flat troponin and mb fractions, his lipitor was held. renal - the patient was followed by the renal team while in house and received intermittent hemodialysis. the patient initially had a tunneled right subclavian hd catheter which was subsequently removed due to bacteremia (see below). the patient eventually had a subsequent right femoral line placed for hemodialysis. until the patient was transferred to a medical team, he continued on hemodialysis. gram negative rod line bacteremia - the ctu team was called to see the patient on , at the dialysis unit when he was noted to be agitated and rigoring. the patient also was noted to have a gram negative rod bacteremia at that time. subsequent culture from the line confirmed the presence of gram negative rods. subsequently the tunneled hd catheter was removed by surgery. he was initially started on gentamicin for treatment of the gram negative rod bacteremia. ceptaz was also added to cover for possible pseudomonal infection. around this time, the patient also had been complaining of some left shoulder pain. there was a concern by the coronary care unit team that the patient could have a possible septic shoulder. a rheumatology consultation was obtained to tap his shoulder. the shoulder was subsequently tapped, however, very little fluid was obtained. subsequent analysis from the joint fluid revealed coagulase negative staphylococcus. he also had a blood culture from , which also grew out coagulase negative staphylococcus. the blood cultures from the catheter tip as well as blood cultures on , grew enterobacter cloacae that was pansensitive. the patient also had an abdominal ct to look for possible intra-abdominal source of his gram negative bacteremia. this showed linear atelectasis and scarring at the left lung base, a 5.0 millimeter nodular opacity in the right middle lobe. there were no abscesses identified. also of note, the patient was started on vancomycin for the gram positive cocci. the patient had several urine cultures which were negative. diabetes mellitus - the intermittently agitated, often combative. a head ct was obtained to rule out intracranial bleed as the patient had recently been on anticoagulation. there was no intracranial hemorrhage or acute pathology. his electrolytes had all been normal during this time. the patient was not felt to be uremic. the most likely etiology of his mental status changes were due to his gram negative rod culture for enterobacter was on . all cultures since then showed no growth. he finished a 2-week course of levofloxacin prior to discharge. episode of hypotension. the patient had an episode of hypotension with systolic blood pressures in the 70s that did not respond to fluids. this occurred after 1.6 liters were taken off during dialysis. the patient was monitored in the icu overnight and received two units of packed red blood cells along with iv fluids and his blood pressure stabilized. again, there was no source for this hypotension. the etiology was likely related to hypovolemia from dialysis along with possible transient bacteremia. after this episode, the patients blood pressure remained stable. change in mental status. the patient had a change in mental status and was transferred to the icu for further monitoring. he came out of the icu the next day and this confusion did not recur. his change in mental status was likely not related to uremia since he had been alkalosis that resolved on its own within a few hours. left shoulder pain. this pain resolved prior to discharge. he had an mri of the left shoulder that had increased enhancement; however, this was after his joint was aspirated. end-stage renal disease. prior to discharge, the patient had a permanent hemodialysis catheter placed. he will continue with his outpatient dialysis regimen. initially, the patient was hyperphosphatemic during hospitalization and was kept on calcium acetate. prior to discharge, this dose was decreased because he was hypophosphatemic. cad. the patient had multiple episodes of ischemic chest pain that resolved with one nitroglycerin. earlier in this hospitalization, he had a cardiac catheterization, which showed three-vessel disease. no intervention was warranted because the patient is a poor surgical candidate. therefore, the chest pain was treated with medical management. his atorvastatin dose was increased to 80 mg by mouth every day. assessment: 47-year-old female with history of substance abuse and question of seizure disorder in the past, asthma status post dilaudid and klonopin overdose who was admitted to the medical intensive care unit with mental status change, rhabdomyolysis, transaminitis, and hypercarbic respiratory failure now transferred to the medicine floor after extubation, improved, for further management. hospital course: 1. medication overdosepsychiatry: on transfer to the medicine floor patient was maintained on a one-to-one sitter and was followed by psychiatry throughout her hospitalization. given her mental status change she was not restarted on her antidepressants. psych and toxicology both were following the patient. as far as from a toxicology standpoint, patient shortly had her n-acetyl cysteine discontinued on transfer to the medicine floor since her liver function tests began to trend downward. it was unlikely that patient overdosed on tylenol, but the n-acetyl cysteine was kept on per toxicology recommendations for hepato protective effects. patient showed no signs of benzodiazepine withdrawal and was maintained on a clinical institute withdrawal assessment scale for several days and required no ativan per ciwa scale. the ciwa scale was subsequently discontinued after events on , which will be discussed below. the patient showed no signs of narcotics withdrawal with no nausea, vomiting, or any other associated symptoms. currently at time of this dictation patient is awaiting inpatient psychiatric treatment either at a rehab facility or at . 1. mental status change: initially on transfer to the medicine floor patients mental status seemed slightly improved, although patient still was disoriented and somewhat confused. it was thought initially that patient most likely had a toxic metabolic encephalopathy from her overdose. initial eeg, which was checked on , was consistent with a diffuse encephalopathy. given patients very high liver function tests, decision was made to hold off on dilantin loading on transfer on given possible hepatotoxic effects on dilantin and a questionable history of seizure disorder in the past but no evidence of seizures at the time of transfer. over the next several days from to patient began to appear more lethargic and her mental status declined. she received no valium to explain her mental status change, and the valium per ciwa scale was discontinued. a head ct was checked on to rule out anoxic brain injury and results showed bilateral hypodense zones in the main inferior orbital portion of both frontal lobes as well as a 2 cm triangular area of decreased absorption in the right frontal lobe suggesting chronic malasic change in frontal lobes. dictation suggested a questionable history of prior trauma, and thus it was thought that her head ct was stable. it was most likely chronic change from previous head injury. it was thought that patient still may likely have a toxic metabolic encephalopathy. however, during the course on patient began to manifest a worsening mental status and stopped following commands and was not responding even to sternal rub. at the same time patient spiked fevers to 102 and 103. at 5 p.m. on patient became tachycardiac in the 100s. systolic blood pressure rose to the 160s when they had previously been in the low 100s and temperature rose to 102 with a respiratory rate of 40. heent exam showed dilated pupils that were minimally active, scleral icterus with bulging sclerae. funduscopic exam was performed which showed no papilledema. neuro exam: as mentioned above, patient was not responding to sternal rub and no withdrawal to pain. she was not opening her eyes or following commands. her deep tendon reflexes were still 2 plus throughout with downgoing babinskis. with the mental status change and fever, it was concerning that patient was either suffering from a seizure, benzodiazepine withdrawal, or some other neurologic process. patient was given 1 mg of ativan times one for question of seizure and benzodiazepine withdrawal but with no effect. stat chest x-ray showed a question of an aspiration pneumonia in the right lower lobe, but this was most likely secondary to mental status change and not the cause of recurrent fever and mental status. blood cultures were drawn which showed no growth. urinalysis was negative. at this point it was attempted to perform an lumbar puncture. head ct had just been performed the night before and there was no papilledema on funduscopic exam. it was felt comfortable to perform the lumbar puncture. several attempts were made by two differential physicians and lumbar puncture was unsuccessful on the evening of with no fluid retrieval. there were no complications at the attempts. abg was also checked at that time and it was 7.54, pco2 of 29, and pao2 of 99, suggesting a respiratory alkylosis. of note, patient was also given two units of fresh frozen plasma for an elevated inr of 1.7 prior to lumbar puncture. since patient was and the lumbar puncture was unsuccessful on the evening of patient was empirically placed on ceftriaxone 2 grams q.d., vancomycin, and flagyl for coverage of aspiration pneumonia. the patient continued to spike fevers throughout the night of and on patient was not responding to sternal rub, following commands, or responding to any pain. her white count was elevated at 15,000. a tox screen was checked which was negative. at 9 a.m. on patient had a grand mal seizure with tonic-clonic movements that were generalized and witnessed by the nursing staff. the seizure resolved after a few seconds. patient was given ativan 2 mg times one, but the seizure had already resolved. her temperature was 103 at that time and her saturations were initially at 95 percent on 2 liters, but they decreased to 70 percent 4 liters. patient was put on 100 percent nonrebreather with only an o2 saturation at 94 percent on nonrebreather. anesthesia was called to intubate the patient for airway protection. they performed a nasotracheal intubation most probably secondary to mouth rigidity. patient was emergently transferred to the medical intensive care unit after intubation. repeat head ct at the micu showed extensive cerebral edema primarily in the white matter in a pattern consistent with reversible leukoencephalopathy syndrome. there were open ventricles and the basal cisternal spaces remain visualized. neurosurgery was consulted and it was felt that patient would most likely benefit from some type of intracranial monitoring device. patient was given mannitol q. 6 hours to keep serum osms less than 320, four units of fresh frozen plasma, and had an intracerebral pressure monitor placed as well as an external ventriculostomy drain. patient had cerebrospinal fluid sample sent from this drain which showed no signs of infection. csf showed only 1 white blood cell and normal glucose and total protein. patient had the drain placed for one day and intracerebral pressures remained stable and the drain was discontinued on by neurosurgery. repeat eeg still showed just diffuse encephalopathy. mri of the head was unrevealing. patient was initially started on dilantin and then transitioned to keppra for ease of usage and no monitoring. patient was also treated with meningitis doses of ceftriaxone 2 grams q. day for a total of a seven-day course completed on for empiric coverage of meningitis since lp could not be performed in the acute setting, and patient had received 24 hours of antibiotics prior to shunt placement and retrieval of csf. even at the time of this dictation it is still unclear why patient had this diffuse cerebral edema, and there have been no clear hypotheses as to why this may have occurred. patient was transferred from the icu back to the medicine floor after improvement of her mental status and discontinuation of the intracerebral pressure monitoring and patient has been alert, lucid, and her mental status has been stable. she is alert enough to give a thorough history and is aware of her surroundings as well as her caretakers, which is quite different from her initial presentation. as far as her seizure disorder, she will continue with the keppra and has not manifested any further seizures. fevers: it is unclear whether patient may have had an aspiration pneumonia so she was treated briefly with a course of clindamycin which was subsequently discontinued after her second transfer to the medicine floor since her chest x-ray from was entirely clear. the patient did complete a full course of seven days for a treatment of meningitis with ceftriaxone 2 grams per day since it was unclear what precipitated her event. patient had a mild low-grade fever on , but this has resolved and she has had no further infectious issues at the time of this dictation. she is currently on no antibiotics. transaminitis: patients liver function tests continued to decline and it was thought likely that patients transaminitis and increased inr were secondary to ischemic liver injury from her initial event. these ast and alt are almost at normal levels at the time of this dictation. rhabdomyolysis: patients rhabdomyolysis also continued to improve throughout the course of her hospitalization. at the time of this dictation her ck level is now down to 500 from a peak of 26,000, and it is felt there is no need to follow these since they have continued to trend downwards. patient was maintained on aggressive intravenous hydration at first and now is continuing on maintenance fluids since she continues to have poor p.o. intake. nutrition goal: patient initially presented with decreased mental status and was not able to take nutrition, but since her mental status has improved patient has passed a speech and swallow evaluation and is tolerating good pos. would continue to encourage fluid intake. access: patient had a right femoral groin line placed initially when she was in the unit and this was subsequently discontinued on her first transfer to the medicine floor. however, when she decompensated with a grand mal seizure and was intubated, she had a left ij placed in the micu. this left ij remained in place until when it was discontinued. the catheter check has been sent for culture since the line site was somewhat erythematous. the culture data is still pending at the time of this dictation. disposition: patient has been working with physical therapy and has been regaining her strength daily. she still requires some assistance with moving around, but this is felt that it would likely improve with further strengthening. the decision is currently being made at the time of this dictation whether to transfer the patient to the inpatient psychiatric unit or to discharge the patient to psychiatric unit at . it has been confirmed that patient does indeed have insurance, medicare. discharge condition: stable. discharge status: still unknown at the time of this dictation but likely to an inpatient psychiatric facility with a rehab potential. a discharge addendum will be added to cover the medications and follow-up plans. , md dictated by: admission date: discharge date: date of birth: sex: m service: general surgery blue briefly, this is a 63-year-old male who presented to the medicine service who had been found down. he went into dts during his hospital course and was transferred to the intensive care unit and intubated. he was slowly weaned from his ventilator, however he began spiking fevers. ct scan revealed what appeared to be a hematoma in his thigh and a drop in his hematocrit. gi was consulted and general surgery was consulted at that time. it was found that ct guided biopsy showed that the question hematoma was actually a subfascial abscess and the patient was taken to the operating room for an incision and drainage and debridement and was found to have a non necrotizing subfascial abscess. the patient was transferred to dr. and general surgery service at that time. the patient was transferred to the intensive care unit postoperatively. past medical history is significant for alcohol abuse and type ii diabetes. medications: unknown. surgical history: unknown. allergies: unknown. physical exam on presentation: vital signs: he was febrile to 103.6. his heart rate was 90 and sinus, 12750, 22 and 100%. he was on an insulin drip, benign. his ............... at 40%. tidal volume is 650. his peep .............. . general: the patient was intubated and sedated. lungs: clear to auscultation. heart: regular rate and rhythm. abdomen: soft, nontender and nondistended. bowel sounds were present. extremities: his left thigh was open with a dressing in place and sanguinous drainage, but otherwise both of his extremities were warm, no edema. labs: his white count was 8.6 at the time postoperative, 23.9 was the hematocrit and platelet count of 327. his coags: his pt was 13.8, ptt of 32.4, inr of 1.4. hospital course: the patient was kept in the intensive care unit and intubated and sedated for a prolonged course for wound changes as well as for slow wean. his temperature curve slowly dropped by his hospital course and by the time he was transferred to the floor he was afebrile. infectious disease was following. he was started on vancomycin, zosyn and clindamycin for coverage. the patient did well after the operation. his blood sugars were difficult to control, which necessitated his insulin drip. he was slowly weaned from his ventilator and did well. during his hospital course, he was able to be extubated and did well post extubation. his white count stayed low and his temperature curve slowly reduced after the drainage. antibiotics were discontinued upon transfer to the floor due to a prolonged afebrile period. the patients wound was changed twice a day with wet to dry dressing changes and after some adequate healing the patient had a wound vac placed with two sponges, one underneath the fascia and one above the fascia. the patients wound continued to heal and the vac changes were done every three days. the patient continued to improve and was able to be extubated from the ventilator with the vac in place. the patient did well and was slowly weaned from this insulin drip. tube feeds were started which were increased slowly to a goal of 70 cc an hour which the patient tolerated and upon transfer to the floor a sliding scale of insulin was used for blood sugar control. center was following for the assistance of controlling blood sugars. postoperatively, after multiple vac dressing changes, the patients thigh was found to be healed well enough to have delayed primary closure. the patient was taken back to the operating room for delayed closure which he tolerated. gi continued to follow and at that time it was found that he was more stable, therefore an esophagogastroduodenoscopy was performed at the same time due to inability to ............... their way. a peg was also placed. the patients hematocrit had stabilized and began to increase after incision and drainage. each ............... revealed old ulcer which was well healing and some traumatic injury from nasogastric tube that had been placed for feeding. postoperatively, he continued to improve. physical therapy was consulted for ambulation and strength. speech and swallow had been consulted to assess his airway and his swallowing ability and gi was consulted for the peg placement. gi decided to defer colonoscopy to an outpatient time because his hematocrit had been stable. the patient had his tube feeds restarted after peg placement which were started at 20 cc an hour and down to a goal of 70 cc an hour. the patient did well with this advancement and at that time his blood sugars were controlled with nph and a sliding scale of insulin. the patient is discharged to va. at the time, he is currently awaiting bed for placement. discharge condition: stable discharge medications: 1. multivitamin 2. protonix 3. metoprolol 50 mg per peg tid 4. epogen 40,000 units subcutaneous q week 5. reglan 10 mg po qid prn 6. iron 325 per peg qd 7. tylenol 325 to 650 per peg q 4 to 6 hours prn 8. heparin 5000 units subcutaneous 9. insulin nph 50 units 10. humalog sliding scale the patient was also discharged on tube feeds promod with fiber at a goal rate of 70 cc an hour. discharge diagnoses: 1. alcohol abuse 2. type ii diabetes 3. subfascial abscess, status post incision and drainage and delayed primary closure discharge instructions: follow up with dr. in two to four weeks and the patient is discharged in stable condition. note: please see addendum for changes in medications, as well as changes in discharge date and location. , m.d. dictated by: medquist36 d: sputum cultures grew out mrsa. the patient was started on a ten day course of vancomycin, which he completed successfully. the patient was slow to wean and was transferred to for weaning. the patient was successfully weaned in the . on he was transferred to the medicine service. while on the medicine service the patient did well from a pulmonary point of view, sating in the mid 90s on 3 liters of initally admitted to the trauma icu where he was evaluated by the trauma and ortho spine team. an mri was attempted to further characterize the spinal injury however, despite sedation the patient was not cooperative with this. upon further discussion with the ortho spine service, it was decided that the best management of the c-spine injury would be a cervical spine collar w torso extension x 3 months. the pt was placed in this collar and subsequently transfered to the floor on hd 4. once on the floor the pts mental status started to decline and he developed a tachycardia. geriatrics, cardiology, and neuro-behavioral consults were obtained. a urinary tract infection was noted and levofloxacin was intially started and broadened to include vancomycin once the culture results returned. in addition, a cta was done to ro pe given the pts tachycardia and increasing oxygen requirement. the cta was neg. on hd 7 the pt spiked a fever to 102.6 and antibiotics and iv fluids were continued. later that morning the patient had a cardiac arrest. the above portion of the dictation including the hpi, past medical history, admission medications, and labs was completed by dr. of the admission date: discharge date: service: trauma age: 86. history of the present illness: mr. is an 86-year-old man, who was brought to the trauma bay in the emergency room after he fell down one flight of stairs. he had a loss of consciousness during his fall, and he was taken to an outside hospital. evaluation at the outside hospital showed a right hemithorax for which a right chest tube was placed. this chest tube put out one liter of blood, and he was transferred to the for further management. at the outside hospital, he was neurologically intact. mr. does not recall the event of his fall. past medical history: 1. cholecystectomy. 2. right hip replacement. 3. incidental 3-cm to 4-cm abdominal aortic aneurysm. allergies: no known drug allergies medications: no known medications. physical examination: examination revealed the following: vital signs: temperature 97, pulse 89, pressure 164100, and oxygen saturation 100%. upon arrival, the patient was intubated. the patient had a 2-cm forehead abrasion. pupils: nonreactive bilaterally. neck: supple with c-collar in place. chest: sounds are coarse bilaterally. there is ecchymosis over the right clavicle. there is a right chest tube in place. abdomen: soft, nondistended. pelvis: stable. extremities: extremities are warm with palpable dp pulses. there were no evident fractures or dislocations of the extremities. there are no stepoffs on the back. rectal: examination revealed no tone, guaiac negative. on discharge, mr. is comfortable in no acute distress. he is oriented to the hospital, although occasionally confused. heart: regular. lungs: lungs are clear. abdomen: soft. peg tube site has a small amount of erythema related to irritation, which is improving. extremities: warm with intact distal pulses. he is able to get out of bed with assist. laboratory data: laboratory data revealed the following: sodium 136, potassium 4.1, chloride 101, bicarbonate 28, bun 22, creatinine 0.9, glucose 86. white count 7.2, hematocrit 30.9, platelet count 380,000, pending urine culture. toxicology screen upon arrival is negative. amylase, upon arrival, is 137. summary of radiographic studies: ct of the head upon arrival showed evidence of subarachnoid hemorrhage within the left temporal lobe. there was no evidence of shift of structures. the ct of the cervical spine showed right transverse process fracture of c7. there were no other fractures of the cervical spine. ct of the chest and abdomen, upon arrival, showed evidence of fracture at the right transverse process fracture at the level of the upper thoracic spine and multiple posterior right rib fractures. there are small, rounded low density lesion in the liver, with a differential diagnosis of cyst versus metastatic disease. percutaneous peg tube was placed on . negative fluid of the c-spine showed no movement of bony alignment. ct angiogram of the head showed a stable left sylvian fissure subarachnoid hemorrhage, bilateral low density subdural fluid collection without any shift and no evidence of intracranial aneurysms or vascular malformations. concise summary of hospital course: mr. was admitted to the intensive care unit after he was transferred from an outside hospital status post fall of one flight of stairs. injuries included subarachnoid hemorrhage in the left sylvian fissure, bilateral subdurals, right clavicle fracture, right c7 transverse process fracture, right hemothorax, and multiple right-sided rib fractures. hospital course: hospital course and progress will be described by systems below. neurological: mr. was admitted with subarachnoid and subdural hemorrhages. neurologicalsurgery consultation was obtained for evaluation of the hemorrhages. over the hospital course he received at least two repeat head cts. on discharge, the subarachnoid hemorrhage has improved and there are no increasing leads. there is no midline shift in the head cts on discharge. mental status over the hospital course has improved. he is now occasionally confused, however, mostly alert and able to read books. ct angiogram was obtained during the admission to rule out vascular injury this was negative for a vascular injury. cardiac: mr. remained stable from a cardiovascular perspective throughout his admission. he was started on beta blockers for hypertension control and on discharge, he is on lopressor. this maintains him at a stable rate and pressure. respiratory: mr. was intubated in the intensive care unit for the first six days of his admission. although awake and alert, his extubation was delivery secondary to a large amount of airway secretions. he was extubated on hospital day 6 and subsequently able to remain extubated. on discharge, he is comfortable and able to cough. he did require suctioning for a large part of his hospital admission. chest tube was weaned by chest x-ray and eventually discontinued. on discharge, the patient is comfortable and saturating well on room air. he does not tolerate much chest pt due to his right rib fractures. he does require suctioning occasionally to help clear his secretions. a swallow study was obtained during the hospital course, which showed aspiration with p.o. intake. therefore, he was kept on npo status to prevent an aspiration. gastrointestinal: early during his hospital course, mr. received j-tube feedings, which he has been tolerating well. he received percutaneous pej tube placement for his tube feeds. after this tube was placed, while he was on the floor, the pej tube was pulled out. the reason for this is unclear, however, this tube was replaced again by the department of radiology and was a pej tube. on discharge, he is tolerating tube feeds at goal. there has been some erythema around the tube site, which is attributed to irritation. this erythema is significantly improved without any antibiotics over the last few days prior to discharge. recommendation is to do dry dressing care for the tube site and keep the tube secured so it is not pulled. mr. is to continue on his tube feeds at goal and can be cycled as needed. he failed his swallow study late in his admission, therefore, because of aspiration risk, he is kept on npo status. on discharge, he is tolerating tube feeds, he is having bowel movements and voiding spontaneously. infectious disease: mr. is off antibiotics for days prior to discharge. his last urine culture showed pseudomonas. however, his white count continued to improve after removal of the foley. he was given two days of ciprofloxacin, after which it was stopped given his afebrile status and improvement in the white count from 12 to 7.2. on discharge, he is voiding spontaneously. he is afebrile. he has a normal white count. urine culture is pending on discharge. one of his sputum culture had h. influenzae, which was believed to be colonization at that time. serial chest x-rays have shown continued improvement. hematology: mr. hematocrit is stable at 30 on discharge. endocrine: mr. has had normal blood sugars on discharge. activity: mr. is able to tolerate out of bed to chair with assist. renal: mr. is able to void spontaneously, making adequate urine on discharge. summary: in summary, mr. presented to the hospital with a right hemothorax, head injury, and multiple right rib fractures and clavicle fractures after a one flight fall. he was intubated upon arrival. he was extubated on hospital day 6. hospital course has been significant for slow progress secondary to his age. he has recovered, however, from his injuries. on discharge, he is alert, with occasional confusion. he is tolerating his tube feeds and goal. he is voiding spontaneously. he is having bowel movements. incidentally, he was found to have multiple low-density areas in the liver, which need followup and workup for ruling out a malignancy. liver function tests were normal during admission. follow-up appointment: the patient is to followup in the trauma clinic in two weeks. phone : . the patient is to followup with the primary care physician in two weeks. the patient will likely need a colonoscopy for further workup. medications on discharge: 1. heparin subcutaneously 5000 units b.i.d. 2. zantac 150 mg per j-tube b.i.d. 3. lopressor 25 mg per j-tube b.i.d. 4. tube feeds, promote with fiber 70 cc per hour per j-tube. 5. ambien 10 mg per j-tube, q.h.s.p.r.n. 6. free water 200 cc per j-tube t.i.d. dressing care: dry dressings to j-tube site t.i.d. and local skin care at the j-tube site as needed. discharge diagnosis: 1. left sylvian fissure subarachnoid hemorrhage. 2. multiple right posterior rib fractures. 3. right c7 transverse process fracture. 4. right clavicle fracture. addendum: mr. cervical spine was cleared later in his hospital course with additional flexion and extension x-rays. the flexion and extension views were inadequate, however, the swimmers view was obtained, which was adequate, which showed no deformity. he took off his collar multiple times during this admission by himself without problems. eventually, the collar cervical spine was cleared and there was no tenderness of his neck. he is able to function without any change in his neurological status for more than a week after the cervical spine clearance. also, for his right clavicle fracture, he has a right arm sling, which can stay on for an additional two weeks. the sling can be removed for his daily activities. , m.d. dictated by: medquist36 d: 08:46 t: 09:17 job: admission date: discharge date: service: trauma addendum: his previous discharge summary had included the his medications and his hospital course has remained stable. he is currently tolerating tube feeds and working with physical therapy, getting out of bed with assistance. , m.d. dictated by: medquist36 admission date: discharge date: date of birth: sex: m service: bone marrow. history of the present illness: the patient is a 23-year-old male with advanced hodgkin disease, initially admitted on to received high-dose cytoxan and total body radiation starting , followed by stem-cell infusion on . he developed neutropenia and fever on day 2 ambisome. during the hospital course he also developed tachycardia and he was found to have pericardial effusion on . repeat echocardiogram on showed tamponade physiology with right ventricular collapse. the patient was then transferred to the medical icu and taken to the catheter laboratory, where 450 cc of blood fluid was withdrawal and pericardial drain was left overnight; 25 cc pericardial fluid and drain was removed on . the patient was then transferred back to the bone marrow transplant service after a echocardiogram showed no changes since the drainage. on , however, the patient was experiencing increasing shortness of breath and concern for worsening confusion resulting in patients transfer back to the medical icu service. repeat echocardiogram showed restrictive tamponade. the patient was monitored with daily echocardiogram in the medical icu. the medical icu course was also significant for the following: 1. acute renal failure thought to be both prerenal from capillary leak and decreased forward flow from tamponade, as well as drug toxicity. the patient was on ambisome and fk506. the fk5-6 was held for the acute renal failure and restarted on . 2. episodes of supraventricular tachycardia, initially treated with diltiazem drip and then switched to po lopressor without further episodes. 3. neutropenic fever. all cultures were negative. initially treated with vancomycin, cefepime, ambisome, cefepime was then switched to imipenem on as per infectious disease recommendation for coverage of .................... 4. white out of the right lung suspected diagnosis of diffuse alveolar hemorrhage, treated with solu-medrol now tapering. bronchoscopy on , revealed some evidence of diffuse alveolar hemorrhage in the left lung only. 5. colonoscopy on , showed no evidence of graft versus host disease. upon transfer back to the bone marrow transplant service, the patient was afebrile. heart rate was 96. blood pressure 10864, breathing 20. he is a thin, young man in no acute distress. pupils were equally round and reactive to light. blister noted on the right upper lobe. diffuse crackles on lung examination. heart examination was significant for s4, no murmurs, regular rate and rhythm. abdominal examination was benign. extremities: no clubbing, cyanosis or edema with 2 pulses. the patient was alert, 55 strength globally. the patient had a white count of 10.6, anemic with hematocrit of 29.6, platelet count 56. coagulations were normal. the patient had the bun and creatinine of 20 and 0.5. the fk506 level was 2.8. while on the bone marrow transplant service, the patient continued to do well with resolving acute renal failure and improved respiratory status, as well as stable heart rate. the patient remained afebrile. the patient was taken off all his antibiotics, as well as the lopressor and remained in sinus rhythm. the patient was seen by the department of cardiology. repeat echocardiogram showed slight decreased in the pericardial effusion. the department of cardiology recommended conservative management of effusion. the patient was then discharged home for daily follow up in the clinic. the patient was discharged in stable condition to home on fk506 4 mg in the morning 5 mg at night; protonix 40 mg po q.d.; prednisone taper starting at 20 mg po q.d.; multivitamin folic acid and glutamine. , m.d. dictated by: medquist36 d: 15:10 t: 15:48 job:

admission date: discharge date: date of birth: sex: f service: history of present illness: this is a 66 year old woman who presented to dr. approximately a year after an episode of acute pancreatitis attributed to alcohol abuse. at the time of that pancreatitis episode, she had a ct scan which revealed a small pseudo cyst. however, on recent ct scan, she was found to still have a small cyst, under the size of one cm, in the head of her pancreas. clinically, she remained well over the previous year, without fevers, chills, nausea, vomiting or other troubles. in , she developed rapid onset of painless jaundice. ct scan at this time revealed only dilated extra hepatic biliary tract. she had a right upper quadrant ultrasound which showed a dilated common bile duct and gallbladder but no evidence of common bile duct stones. endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography was performed and a high grade focal stricture of the distal common bile duct was observed. a stent was placed and she was sent to dr. for evaluation. the patient denies fevers, chills or other symptoms of cholangitis. she also denies weight loss, history of cancer or recent exacerbation of alcohol use. past surgical history: breast biopsy, appendectomy, a remote laparoscopy. past medical history: hypercholesterolemia; paroxysmal atrial fibrillation; mild mitral insufficiency and an alcohol history of four manhattans a day. medications: lanoxin, norvasc, zestril, zocor, allopurinol, axid, folic acid and multi-vitamins. allergies: no known drug allergies. social history: she is a retired teacher. physical examination: on examination, she has jaundice and has scleral icterus. the rest of her head, eyes, ears, nose and throat examination was normal. she had normal carotid pulses without bruits and no jugular venous distention. her chest was clear and her heart was regular rate and rhythm. she did have grade ii out of 6 mid systolic ejection murmur, heard best at the apex. her abdomen was soft, nondistended and nontender. her gallbladder was not palpable. hospital course: she underwent a high contrast ct arterial study and was then brought into , where she underwent on , a whipple procedure. postoperatively, she was placed on prophylactic benzodiazepine for possible delirium tremens. she was also placed on subcutaneous heparin, zantac, testall and her pain was controlled with an epidural. initially, she was neo-synephrine dependent and she had very subtle electrocardiogram changes postoperatively. cardiology was consulted and a myocardial infarction was ruled out with negative enzymes. she remained in the intensive care unit overnight, secondary to the neo drip. however, throughout, she had excellent urine output. the evening of postoperative day one, her epidural was switched to a pca for better pain control; however, she was found to be over narcotized and required a narcan drip to alleviate this problem. on postoperative day number two, she was doing well and she was transferred to the floor. over the next few days, she continued to do well. on postoperative day four, she required some lasix for mild pulmonary edema on clinical examination. this resolved with upright positioning and the diuresis with the lasix. on postoperative day number seven, she was noted to have a large amount of wound drainage and her wound was open for copious amounts of somewhat enteric looking drainage. she went for ct scan to rule out fistula or leak. the only finding was a possible smb clot. over this time as well, her platelets dropped from 325 to 64 and then by postoperative day number seven, down to nine. hit antibody was sent. all heparin was removed from her lines and subcutaneous. zantac was stopped. dic laboratory studies were sent and found to be unremarkable. we placed venodynes on her legs for deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis and requested a hematology consult. the hematology consult agreed with our management and furthermore, advised holding any anticoagulation, secondary to a risk of bleed, given that her platelet count was only nine. her platelet count remained nine over postoperative day eight. early in the morning on postoperative day number nine, she became anuric, hypotensive and her hematocrit was found to have dropped to 22. she was transferred to the intensive care unit. swan-ganz was placed for fluid management. she was actively resuscitated with blood products and fluid. she was taken to the operating room for exploration of possible abdominal bleed. upon opening the abdomen in the operating room, however, the small bowel was found to be entirely infarcted with catastrophic abdominal findings. she was reclosed without any further intervention and brought back to the intensive care unit. we supported her blood pressure with pressors and fluids until her family could be fully present. at that point, she was made comfort measures only. she expired. , m.d. dictated by: medquist36 d: t: 05:07 job:
